The teachings of ÅšÄkyamuni are profoundly deep and the ultimate truth is profound.

The Imperial Edict on Explaining the Meaning of the Two Truths (21) The Imperial Edict on Explaining the Meaning of the Two Truths and Answering Questions The principle of the two truths is truly profound and abstruse.
If one does not empty one's mind,
one will not be able to understand its vastness.
The way to illuminate the truth
is not just one.
To discuss it in brief, it does not go beyond the realm and wisdom.
Sometimes it clarifies the meaning based on the realm,
sometimes it reveals the practice based on wisdom.
As for the two truths, it is precisely clarifying the meaning based on the realm.
If one is confused about the direction, the three non-existences will not cease.
If one understands the principle, the myriad afflictions will be dispelled.
As for the so-called two truths,
One is true reality.
Two are called conventional reality.
True reality is also called the ultimate reality.
Conventional reality is also called worldly reality.
True reality and conventional reality are established with fixed substance as their names.
Ultimate reality and worldly reality are established with praise and depreciation as their eyes.
If we speak in sequence,
We should say one is true reality,
And two is conventional reality.
One and two combined,
The number becomes three.
Not only does the number exceed two,
It is also called having a sequence,
Which is not convenient for the meaning.ğŸ”½Since truth does not depend on convention to exist,
Convention also does not arise due to truth.
It can only be said that there is one truth and one convention.
Truth is the meaning of reality.
It is precisely equality, with no other dharma
That can be mixed in between.
Convention is precisely the meaning of accumulation.
This dharma can arise,
Floating and false, arising and creating.
The ultimate meaning is
Established as a beautiful name within the realm of non-arising.
It is said that this Dharma is the most supreme and wonderful, and there is nothing that can compare to it.
World has the meaning of separation.
Birth and death flow and move, without a phase of abiding.
The Nirvana Sutra says:
What is known by those who have left the world is called the ultimate truth.
What is known by worldly people is called worldly truth.
This is textual evidence for the principle of praise and criticism.
The two truths have different names and distinctions.
True, conventional, worldly, etc. are explained with one meaning.
The ultimate truth is explained with two meanings.
It is said that since this principle and virtue are the ultimate, the ultimate truth is also the ultimate.
Since the world is deceptive and false, there is no other meaning.
Therefore, it is only given the name world.
Truth has the meaning of being true and real.ğŸ”½True reality is true and real.
Conventional reality is true and real as conventional.
True reality is free from existence and non-existence.ğŸ”½Conventional reality is both existence and non-existence.
Both existence and non-existence are provisional names.
Free from existence and non-existence is the middle way.
This is truly the middle way.
Taking non-arising as its essence.
Since the conventional is a provisional name,
Taking arising dharmas as its essence.
(Shi Hui Chao of Nanjian Temple discusses the meaning of the two truths) (21) Shi Hui Chao of Nanjian Temple asks:
False and deceptive activity is called the conventional.
Free from existence and non-existence is called the true.
I am not sure whether falsity and deception are of the same essence as the true or different.
Ling Zhi replies:
The essence of arising dharmas is known by worldly people.
The essence of non-arising is known by those beyond the world.
Based on people, the treatise is composed.
It should be explained like this.ğŸ”½If discussing the true, it is emptiness.
The conventional points to emptiness as existence.
Based on this meaning, they cannot be distinguished.
Furthermore, it is asked:
Since the true and conventional are said to be of the same essence,
I am not sure whether the true meaning also has activity.
Does activity automatically occur without being related to the true meaning?
Ling Zhi further replies:
The true principle is tranquil and has no appearance of activity.
Ordinary beings, due to delusion and ignorance, themselves give rise to false views and agitation.
Again, he asked:ğŸ”½I am not sure whether there is agitation and ordinary beings have false views,
or there is no agitation and ordinary beings have false views.
The imperial decree replied again:
If there is agitation, it cannot be called false views.
Because there is no movement but seeing movement, it is therefore false views.
Again, he asked:
If the Dharma has no agitation, then there should only be one truth.
The imperial decree replied again:
This principle is always tranquil, this is one truth by itself.
Falsely seeing agitation is also one truth.
According to this, there should be two, not one.
Again, he asked:
Is there false seeing or is there no false seeing?
The imperial decree replied again:
From the perspective of people, there is this false seeing.
Again, he asked:
If, because of speaking from the perspective of people, there is false seeing,
speaking from the perspective of the Dharma, one should not see movement.
The imperial decree replied again:
The Dharma is without movement.
It does not prevent those with false views from seeing their own movement.
30. Prince of Jin'an Xiao Gang inquires about the meaning of the two truths (21) The Magistrate of Danying, Prince of Jin'an Xiao Gang, asked:
Understanding the meaning depends on the person. Is there birth or non-birth?
I have not yet discerned whether floating and empty is the same as non-birth.
Is it just one essence or is there a difference?
Ling Zhi replied:
The seen by ordinary beings' minds sees its movement.
The seen by sages sees its non-birth.
Relying on benevolence to discuss it is indeed a different essence.
If speaking of their identity, then it does not become different.
As explained above, I will not discuss it much further.
He also asked:
If the true is not different from the conventional,
and the conventional is not different from the true,
how can the essence of the born dharmas seen by ordinary beings
be the essence of non-birth seen by sages?
Ling Zhi replied:ğŸ”½The conventional is known to be the true.
The true is seen to be the conventional.
Speaking from this perspective, there is naturally no difference.
Discerning the seen from the perspective of people, there is naturally the distinction of birth and non-birth.
He also asked:ğŸ”½I have not yet understood.
Since the essence of conventional truth is said to be floating and illusory,
how can this floating and illusory be seen within the true reality?
Ling Zhi replied:
The essence of true reality itself is free from floating and illusory.
Deluded ones mistakenly construct it
and call it existent.
This does not harm the true reality, which is itself empty and profound.
He also asked:
The view of the sages does not see flowing movement.
The view of ordinary beings themselves see flowing movement.
Since there is flowing and not flowing,
the foolish think they cannot be one.
Ling Zhi replied:
I do not say that flowing and not flowing are each a separate essence.
I am simply saying that ordinary beings mistakenly see this flow within the non-flowing.
Based on this, it can be said to be one.
He also asked:
The essence of true quiescence is originally non-flowing.
Ordinary beings see flowing, but it is not apart from the true essence.
Then there is only one true reality, not two truths.
Ling Zhi replied:
The essence always mutually includes, and the principle cannot be different.
But ordinary beings see it as floating and empty, while sages perceive it as truly tranquil.
Based on the perspectives of ordinary beings and sages, the names of the two truths can be established.
(Shi Huiyan of Zhaoti Temple asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) Shi Huiyan of Zhaoti Temple asks:
Ordinary beings see the conventional with arising phenomena as their essence.
Sages see the true with non-arising as their essence.
I am not sure whether arising and non-arising
are only seen as different. Based on what meaning can they be distinguished as one?
Ling Zhi's reply:ğŸ”½Ordinary people grasp existence where there is no fabrication.
Sages discern non-existence where there is existence.
Existence and non-existence are mutually inclusive, thus discussing the one essence.
Another question:
I am not sure whether this can be discussed as one.
What is the name of this one?
Ling Zhi's reply:
It is precisely because existence is not different from non-existence and non-existence is not different from existence,
that it is called one. There is no other name.
Another question:ğŸ”½If non-existence is not different from existence,
and existence is not different from non-existence,
only one is seen.
Why are there two?
The Imperial Decree's Response:
Ordinary beings see existence, while sages see non-existence.
Since these two views are divided, they form two truths.
Furthermore, it is asked:
Since sages see non-existence, there is nothing to be called truth.
Since ordinary beings see existence, how can it be called truth?
The Imperial Decree's Response:
The sages' seeing of non-existence is truth for the sages.
Ordinary beings consider it to be existent.
Therefore, it is truth for ordinary beings.
(Shi Yunzong of Qixuan Temple asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) Shi Tanzong of Qixuan Temple asks:
Do sages see the truth of the world or do they not see the truth of the world?
The Imperial Decree's Response:
Sages know that ordinary beings see the truth of the world as existent.
If we discuss the sages, they no longer see this.
Furthermore, it is asked:
Since sages do not see the truth of the world,
how do they use the truth of the world to teach and transform sentient beings?
The Imperial Decree's Response:ğŸ”½Sages are free from delusion and do not see the truth of the world themselves.
This does not prevent sages from knowing what is seen by ordinary beings.
Therefore, following the feelings of beings, he speaks of the two truths.
Moreover, he asks:
The sage knows the worldly truth seen by ordinary beings.
Are these ordinary beings?
The imperial decree replies:
These ordinary beings are the worldly truth.
The sage also does not see these ordinary beings.
Moreover, he asks:
Since the sage does not see ordinary beings,
how does he know that ordinary beings see the worldly truth?
The imperial decree replies:
Although the sage himself is not an ordinary being,
he is still able to know that there are ordinary beings.
They consider themselves to exist.
Therefore, following their feelings, he speaks of the worldly truth for them.

(Wang Gui, the Middle-Ranking Cavalier Attendant of the Minister of Education, asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) Wang Gui, the Middle-Ranking Cavalier Attendant of the Minister of Education, asks:
I do not know if the true and the conventional are different,
how can they be said to be mutually inclusive?
The imperial decree replies:
What the sage attains, he sees as non-existent by himself.
What ordinary people attain, they see as existent by themselves.
Their views are different.
This does not prevent the conventional from not being outside the true.
Moreover, he asks:
I do not know how, since there is no difference,
there can be two meanings in the substance.ğŸ”½Is it that the meaning is separate from the substance,
or is it that the meaning is the same as the substance?
Let Zhizhe answer.
Not mutually emerging is called one substance.
The difference in views between the foolish and the sage naturally forms different meanings.
Moreover, I ask.
Do ordinary people only see the conventional or can they also see the true?
Let Zhizhe answer.
They only get to see the conventional, not the true.
Moreover, I ask.
Since the substance is mutually inclusive, why don't they see the true?
Let Zhizhe answer.
If the ordinary see the true, they should not see the conventional.
Since seeing the conventional is false, how can they see the true?
(Shi Sengqian of Linggen Temple asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) Shi Sengqian of Linggen Temple asks:
If the first is taken to be the meaning of being faultless,
this is a name of praise.
The true, which is apart from the conventional, should also be a name of praise.
Let Zhizhe answer:
This very true substance,
cannot be said to be praise.
Since the ultimate truth is given a beautiful name,
it is praised.
Moreover, it is asked:
Since the one who is unsurpassed can be praised,
the essence of self is true.
Why is it not praised?
The decree responds:
The reason the one who is unsurpassed can be praised is
because the essence of self is true, and it is also my truth.
Therefore, it is not praise.
Moreover, it is asked:
The one who has no faults
can be praised.
I am not false, so why is it not praise?
The decree responds:
Not being false is the name of the inherent essence.
It is like calling a person who understands the meaning of a dharma one who understands the meaning.
It is precisely the name of the actual essence.
How could it be praise?
Moreover, it is asked:
This dharma cannot be surpassed.
How can it be praise?
The decree responds:
Since it is said to be unsurpassed,
how could it not be praise?
35. Luo Ping Hou Xiao Zheng Li asks about the meaning of the two truths (21) Luo Ping Hou Xiao Zheng Li asks:
I have not yet understood whether the conventional truth is a produced dharma or not.
The master's answer:
The essence of the conventional truth is precisely a produced dharma.
He asks again:
Since the conventional is a horizontal view,
how can there be production?
The master answers:
The horizontal view is considered to be existent,
therefore there is production.
He asks again:
The horizontal view is considered to be existent,
but in reality it is without dharma.
Since there is no reality, what is said to be produced?
The master answers:ğŸ”½This very produced dharma is called the horizontal view,
and this very horizontal view is called the produced dharma.
He asks again:
If it is a horizontal view, it should not have production.
If it must have production, how can it be called a horizontal view?
The master answers:
Since it is said to be a horizontal view,
it is actually without production.
But the horizontal view is considered to be existent,
there is this horizontally produced.
36 (Xiao Gong, Marquis of Hengshan, asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) Xiao Gong, Marquis of Hengshan, asks:
I have not yet understood why the ultimate truth has a name,
but why does the conventional truth alone have no name?
The imperial decree replies:
Since the conventional is a floating custom, there is no meaning to be distinguished.
He asks again:
If there is no meaning to be distinguished,
why is it called truth?
The imperial decree replies:
The common people see it as true,
so the name of truth is established.
He asks again:
If the common people see it and can receive the name of truth,
then they should also see it and be able to receive the name of meaning.
The imperial decree replies:
The common people see it as true,
so the name of truth can be established.
The floating customs have no meaning,
so how can it be forcibly named meaning?
He asks again:
Although the floating customs have no real meaning,
they are not without the meaning of floating customs.
Since there is this floating custom,
why can it not receive the name of meaning?
The imperial decree replies:
Precisely because it is superficial, there is no meaning to be discerned.
If there is meaning to be discerned, how can it be called superficial?
(Monk Huai of Zhongxing Temple asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) Monk Huai of Zhongxing Temple asks:
The imperial decree explains:ğŸ”½The true does not depart from the superficial.
The superficial does not depart from the true.
I do not yet understand that the true is without characteristics.
The superficial has characteristics.
Characteristics and no characteristics are different.
How can they have the same essence?
The imperial decree replies:
Characteristics and no characteristics are not the same here.
But what the ordinary person sees as existent
Is precisely what the sage sees as non-existent.
Using this for discussion,
It can be said to be no different.
Moreover, it is asked:
Since it is one dharma,
How can it be seen as two?
Since the seeing is already two, how can it be one dharma?
The imperial decree replies:
The principle is not two.
It follows what is seen by beings.
Therefore, it can be two.
Moreover, it is asked:
Since the seeing is already two,
How can it not contradict itself?
The Imperial Decree's Response.
If the Dharma were truly dual,
It could be contradictory.
The Dharma is always non-dual,
People themselves see it as dual.
Based on this, we compose this treatise.
How can it be contradictory?
Moreover, it is asked:
People see it as dual,
One can speak of two people.
The principle is already one,
How can there be duality?
The Imperial Decree's Response:
Although the principle is non-dual, it becomes dual based on people.
(The fourth son of King Shixing, Xiao Ying, asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) The fourth son of King Shixing, Xiao Ying, asks:
The ultimate truth is the ultimate meaning.
Are its virtues also ultimate?
The Imperial Decree's Response:
Since the meaning is ultimate,
Its virtues are also ultimate.
Moreover, it is asked:
Simply speaking of the ultimate,
It already includes both meaning and virtue.
How can it be further added with the word meaning to cause redundancy?
The Imperial Decree's Response:
Simply speaking of the ultimate, the meaning is still obscure.
The first view can be said to be perfect in meaning.
Moreover, I ask:
If it is further added with the word meaning, it can be said to be perfect.
Why not add the word virtue to make it perfect?
The imperial decree replies:
The first is virtue.
How could it wait to be added again?
But by adding the word meaning, both virtue and meaning are beautiful.
Moreover, I ask:
Simply calling it the first is enough to show its beauty.
Adding the word meaning seems to be limiting it.
The imperial decree replies:
The first expresses virtue.
And adding the word meaning again.
Both beauties are presented together.
How could it be limiting?
(Prince Xiao Li of Wu Ping asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) Prince Xiao Li of Wu Ping asks:
The general meaning says:
The ultimate truth and the conventional truth.
The name is established by praise and depreciation.
The true and conventional two truths are established by defining their essence.
Investigating the principle of ultimate truth, it is already wondrously beyond words and thoughts.
I do not know how there can be a defined essence.
The imperial decree replied:
Discussing its signlessness, there is neither true nor false.
Relying on names and signs, it is said that the essence is truly established.
Again, it is asked:
If the truth has no essence,
Now, relying on words to distinguish the essence,
I have not yet examined the signlessness of the truth.
Why not rely on words to distinguish the signs?
The imperial decree replied:
Relying on words to distinguish the essence is still feared to depreciate virtue.
If one further relies on words to distinguish the signs, then there are vain entanglements in the profound mystery.
Again, it is asked:
The truth is profoundly empty and apart from words and explanations.
Now that it is called true,
Isn't it relying on words to distinguish the signs?
The imperial decree replied:
Relying on this name,
The name itself is the sign.
It does not harm this principle of signlessness and empty tranquility.
Again, it is asked:
I have not yet examined this reliance on words to distinguish the essence.
Is it in accord with principle or not in accord with principle?
The imperial decree replied:
Speaking of the nameless, the name is not completely in accord with principle.
Again, it is asked:
If one relies on words to distinguish the name,
The name is not in accord with principle,
I do not know what this entrustment will be about.
The Imperial Response:
Although it is not in accordance with principle,
in order to guide sentient beings, names and forms must be spoken of.
(Song Xi Temple Monk Hui Ling Asking about the Meaning of the Two Truths) (21) Song Xi Temple Hui Ling asked:
The ultimate truth takes non-arising as its essence.
The conventional truth takes arising phenomena as its essence.
It is said that non-arising is precisely arising,
and arising is precisely non-arising.ğŸ”½Is it that the essence is mutually inclusive,
or is it that the meaning is mutually inclusive?
The Imperial Response said:
The essence is mutually inclusive,
but the meaning is not mutually inclusive.
Hui Ling further asked:
Since the meaning is not inclusive,
how can the essence be inclusive?
The Imperial Response said:
The ordinary see it as existent,
while the sages perceive it as non-existent.
Based on seeing, there is a difference,
but in terms of the essence, it is always inclusive.
Hui Ling further asked:
Since the essence is not dual, why is there a need for inclusion?
The Imperial Response said:
If the essence is not separate, the two perspectives see it as dual.
Since the two views are different, it is necessary to clarify the identity of the essence.
Moreover, I ask:
If it is as you understand,
then the identity is indeed explained in terms of the person.
Please reply:
The two views are distinguished in terms of the person.
The reason for the name of the two truths arises from this.
To explain the identity in terms of the person's views is also greatly problematic.
(The fifth son of King Shixing, Xiao Ye, asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) The fifth son of King Shixing, Xiao Ye, asks:
The ultimate truth is called true.
Is it truly true?
Please reply:
It is truly true.
Moreover, I ask:
When bodhisattvas unite with the truth,
do they forget the conventional or forget the truth?
Please reply:
They forget the conventional and forget the truth.
Therefore, it is said that they unite with the truth.
Moreover, I ask:
If they forget the conventional and forget the truth, and therefore unite with the truth,
what is meant by true truth when forgetting the conventional and forgetting the truth?
Please reply:
If they retain the conventional and retain the truth, what is meant by true truth?
Precisely because of the double negation, it is called the real truth.
Moreover, I ask:
If forgetting the conventional and forgetting the truth is the real truth,
then forgetting the truth and forgetting the conventional should also be the real conventional.

(Shi Fa-chong of Xuanwu Temple asks about the meaning of the two truths) (21) Fa-chong of Xuanwu Temple asks:
